text: The Bony Pelvis Ms S Govender shavana.govender@wits.ac.za ANAT 2020 2023 References • Clinically Oriented Anatomy (8th ed.) • Moore and Dalley • Pelvic girdle • Chapters 3 and 4 • Gray’s Anatomy for Students • Netter’s Atlas • Abraham and McMinns Atlas Pelvic girdle • Consists of 3 bones: • Sacrum • 2 x os coxae • Each os coxae consist of 3 bones: • Ilium • Ischium • Pubis Sacrum • 5 fused sacral vertebrae • Upside down triangle • Base • Apex • Ventral surface (pelvic) • Dorsal surface • 2 lateral margins Sacrum – Base • Supports weight of vertebral column • Superior surface – S1 • Articular process – L5 • Anterior margin prominent – sacral promontory • Sacral canal and sacral foramina • Wide wing-like ala form • Linea terminalis – pelvic brim Sacrum • Apex • Projects downwards • Joined to coccyx • Pelvic Surface • Concave – smooth • Transverse ridges - fusion • 4 anterior sacral foramina Sacrum • Dorsal Surface • Convex and roughened • Median sacral crest • Fused spinous processes • Medial sacral crest • Fused articular processes – Indistinct ridge • Lateral sacral crest • Fused transverse processes • Sacral hiatus – projection = sacral horns • Posterior sacral foramina Sacrum • Lateral Surfaces • Ear-shaped structure • Auricular facets/ surface • Sacro-iliac joints • Behind facet – sacral tuberosity 3-5 rudimentary segments Remanent of embryonic tail Coccyx Os coxa • Large, irregular bone • Cup-shaped hollow • Acetabulum (articulates head of femur) • Forms anterior + lateral walls of pelvis • Joined anteriorly – pubic symphysis • Joined posteriorly – sacro-iliac joint • Consists of 3 parts: • Ilium – 2/5 • Ischium – 2/5 • Pubis – 1/5 • Joined at acetabulum • Ossifies at the age of 16 Ilium • Superior margin • Upper arched margin known as iliac crest • S-shaped (above) • Anterior two-thirds • Posterior third • Anterior two-thirds of the margin • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) • Anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) ASIS: inguinal ligament & sartorius Ilium • Posterior third of the margin • Posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) • Posterior inferior iliac spine (PIIS) • Just inferior to posterior inferior iliac spine - greater sciatic notch (shared by ilium + ischium) Ilium • Gluteal surface – lateral surface • Divided into 4 areas by 3 gluteal lines • Lines distinct or vague • Posterior gluteal line • Small posterior area gives origin to the gluteus maximus • Anterior gluteal line • Large anterior area gives origin to gluteus minimus • Between two gluteal lines - gives origin to gluteus medius • Inferior gluteal line • Attachment of capsule of hip joint Ilium • Pelvic surface – medial surface • 3 areas • Iliac fossa – faces the greater pelvis (wing/ala) • Iliacus m. • Arcuate line • Separates iliac fossa from the lesser pelvis • Posterior sacropelvic surface • Smooth anterior surface = auricular surface • Joins to sacrum (sacroiliac joint) • Rough posterior area = iliac tuberosity Ischium • U-shaped • Consists of the following: • Body • Contributes 2/5 of the acetabulum anteriorly • Ischial spine • Lesser sciatic notch posteriorly • Ramus • Contributes to formation of obturator foramen • Joins to inferior pubic ramus and forms one pillar of the pubic arch • Ischial tuberosity • Where the body and ramus join • Rough surface for muscles Pubis • Consists of 3 parts • Body • Superior ramus • Contributes to the acetabulum • Inferior ramus • Contributes to obturator foramen Pubis: Body • Flat, quadrangular bone • 3 borders, 3 surfaces • Lateral border: contributes to obturator foramen • Inferior border: continuous inferior ramus • Superior border: pubic crest ends pubic tubercle • Medial surface: forms pubic symphysis, attached by interpubic disc (fibro-cartilaginous joint) • Anterior surface: directed adductor compartment (5 muscles) • Posterior surface: separated from bladder by retropubic space Pubis: Superior ramus • 1/5 of acetabulum, • 3 borders, 3 surfaces • Anterior border - obturator crest • Posterior border - pectineal line • Inferior border - sharp - upper margin of obturator foramen • Pectineal/superior surface – almost triangular • Posterior surface – lies in relation retropubic space • Inferior surface – roof for tunnel • Inferior ramus – Ischiopubic ramus Acetabulum • Cavity – head of femur • Hip joint • Formed by ilium, ischium, pubis • Smooth horseshoe-shaped articular surface • Space in between = acetabular notch – transverse ligament • Acetabular fossa • Acetabular margin • Acetabular labrum • Surrounds head of femur Pelvis - Functions • Protects pelvic organs • Affords attachment to muscles • Contributes with transfer of weight • Helps with movement • Important role during parturition Pelvis • Separated into two parts • False/Greater pelvis • Wide upper part of pelvic girdle • Lateral border - alae of ilium • Posterior border - lower lumbar vertebrae • Anterior border - abdominal wall • True/Lesser pelvis • Lower basin-shaped part • Anterior wall - 2 pubic bones with rami • Lateral wall - ischia with rami and acetabulum • Posterior wall - sacrum and coccyx • Divided into 3 areas • Inlet, cavity and outlet Pelvis - Inlet • Formed or bordered by: • Pubis symphysis • Pubic crest • Pubic tubercle • Pectineal line • Iliopubic eminence • Arcuate line • Ala • Promontorium Pelvis - Outlet • Formed or bordered by: • Pubic symphysis • Inferior ramus of pubis and ischium (pubic arch) • Ischial tuberosity • Sacrotuberous lig. • Coccyx FEMALE MALE General Lighter & slender Heavier & more robust False pelvis Shallow Deep True pelvis Wider Narrow Ischia Turned outwards Turned inwards Pelvic inlet Kidney-shaped Heart-shaped Subpubic angle Obtuse (>90°) Acute (<90°) Obturator foramen Oval Round Greater sciatic notch Wide Narrow Sacrum Short, wide, less arched Long, narrow, arched Joints of the pelvis • Pubic Symphysis • Cartilaginous joint • Bony elements: 2 pubic bones • Fibrocartilaginous disc = interpubic disc • Limited movement is possible • Sacroiliac joint • Synovial joint • Sacro-iliac ligaments • Bony elements: Ala of sacrum + articular surface on ilium • Movement minimal Ligaments • Sacrotuberous ligaments • Sacrum and ischial tuberosity • Sacrospinous ligaments • Sacrum and ischial spine • Ligaments change the greater and lesser sciatic notches into the foramina • Obturator membrane attaches onto the obturator foramen Walls & floors of pelvic cavity • Anteroinferior pelvic wall • Bodies & rami: pubic bones & symphysis • Bears weight of bladder • Lateral pelvic walls • Obturator foramen: obturator membrane • Obturator internus muscle • Obturator fascia • Posterior pelvic wall • Piriformis muscle • Ligaments (ant. sacropelvic, sacrospinous & sacrotuberous) • Pelvic floor (pelvic diaphragm) • Coccygeus muscle • Levator ani muscle • Puborectalis, pubococcygeus & iliococcygeus Obturator internus • Origin • Pelvic surface ilium, ischium & obturator membrane • Insertion • Greater trochanter (medial surface) • Action • Lateral rotation • Innervation • Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2) Piriformis • Origin • Pelvic surface: S2-S4 segments, sup. margin greater sciatic notch & sacrotuberous lig. • Insertion • Greater trochanter (superior border) • Action • Lateral rotation • Innervation • Ant. rami S1 & S2 Coccygeus • Origin • Ischial spine • Insertion • Sacrum (inferior end) and coccyx • Action • Support pelvic viscera • Innervation • Branches: S4 & S5 spinal nerves Levator ani (PR, PC, IC) • Puborectalis (Puborectal sling) • Body of pubis → Perineal body & rectum • Pubococygeus • Body of pubis → Anococcygeal lig. • Iliococcygeus • Tendinous arch → Anococcygeal lig. • Action • Support pelvic viscera • Innervation • Nerve to levator ani, inferior anal nerve & coccygeal plexus
